contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh had chosen David to be king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will become a ruler over my people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases share similar meanings. The idioms "we are yours" and "we are on your side" both mean that the men support David. Alternate translation: "We are devoted to you, David. We support you, son of Jesse" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: We are yours, David. We are on your side, son of Jesse

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases share similar meanings and are used for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you descendants of Israel his servant, you people of Jacob, his chosen ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. Here "word" refers to the covenant. Alternate translation: "Keep his covenant in mind forever, the promise that he made for a thousand generations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Keep his covenant ... for a thousand generations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both "the covenant" and "the oath" refer to the same promise that Yahweh made to his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the covenant that he made with Abraham, and his oath to Isaac

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phrases "when your days are fulfilled" and "go to your fathers" have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. They both are polite ways to refer to death and dying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: when your days are fulfilled for you to go to your fathers

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize that David's dynasty will last forever. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will set him over my house and in my kingdom forever, and his throne will be established forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You have honored your servant. You have given your servant special recognition

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meaning and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: there is none like you, and there is no God besides you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have about the same meaning and are repeated here for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You, Yahweh, have blessed it, and it will be blessed forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean the same thing, stated in different ways in order to emphasize that Solomon should not be afraid. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Be strong and courageous ... Do not fear or be discouraged

contextId.occurrenceNote: The second phrase defines the first phrase. The "ark of the covenant" is spoke of as Yahweh's footstool to picture God on his throne, with his feet resting on his footstool, which represents all that is in submission to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the ark of the covenant of Yahweh; a footstool for our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: "a man accustomed to war and have shed blood." Both descriptions emphasize the same thing, namely that David had killed people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a man of war and have shed blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and the second describes the first. Even though all of the people of Israel are not present, those present represent all of Israel. Alternate translation: "all you people of Israel, in this assembly for Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: all Israel, this assembly for Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh knows the thoughts and motives of every person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: searches all hearts and understands every motivation of everyone's thoughts

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will always be with Solomon. Also, this can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: "He will always be with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will not leave you nor abandon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases emphasize that Solomon received special favor from Yahweh, which made him Israel's greatest and most powerful king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh greatly honored Solomon before all Israel ... bestowed on him greater power
